Message.Title: Lets Play Yahoo Poker. The "Tell" why Alibaba will IPO in 2013...like in poker, watch a player on the strenght of his hand
Message.Msg: by his actions (tell). So the poker table is the world stock market. The players at the poker table (stock market) is watching. So what does Jack Ma do? He announced his retirement in May. I would consider his announcement a "Raise" pre flop as he is holding pocket ACES (IPO). Why? Because if his pocket ACES holds up, he will make a ton of money. So how will he bet to make sure his pocket ACES holds up after the flop? He has to bet aggressively during the flop, the turn and the river card. How does he do this? The answer my friends was his retirement, so he can devote the big bet on the flop, big bet on the turn, and big bet on the river time and effort during the "road show" of the IPO. Per Eric Jackson who has been spot on: "Even though Jack Ma will continue to be involved in the business, why wouldnâ€™t he want to be a major part of an IPO road show? Thatâ€™s not to say he canâ€™t be in the future but he certainly is probably closer to the business now than he will be in two years. It would seem to make more sense to have him part of a road show now rather than later." Yup, investors would want to hear from Jack Ma the founder and visionary NOW, not from his successors who might stumble two years from now.

Message.Title: Yahoo may blow away earnings and here is why.. IMHO...
Message.Msg: Ad revenues have picked up across the board and with so much attention on Yahoo from the media lately it seems that companies may be turning to them for placing their ads. Secondly, Alibaba did $3 billion in revenue on November 11th. No one knows the profit margin on that but we may find out Monday. I believe that is why Yahoo pushed back their earnings announcement a week. It originally, I believe, was January 23rd. I believe they wanted to know when Alibaba could supply their numbers to them. I also believe Yahoo has not been buying back shares. One reason for this may be they might be in takeover talks. I believe the buyback was halted weeks ago. I am only guessing here because I do not know the rules a company must follow when in takeover talks. I can only imagine companies stop buybacks because it would constantly change the takeover price if they keep buying. HMM.. I just don't know it is just a gut feeling. all jmho
